RelatedSentence: What : The Allegheny County Health Department and University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health will host a conference on climate change and its possible effects on public health .
Climate change in Pennsylvania could mean more than warming temperatures and intense storms .

And Lyme disease could spread , according to experts scheduled to speak at a conference on Monday organized by the Allegheny County Health Department and the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health .

âTo be prepared for the future , you have to pay attention to the changing climate , â said Raymond Najjar , a professor of oceanography in the meteorology department at Penn State University , who will open the conference .

A0: one of the authors of the 2009 Pennsylvania Climate Impact Assessment
RelatedSentence: It determined the state 's overall climate could warm by up to 7 degrees by the end of the century .
Precipitation could increase by as much as 10 percent during the spring and 15 percent in winter , it said .
If the state does nothing to curb greenhouse emissions , summers in Pennsylvania could feel like summers in Georgia , with hotter and more humid conditions , Najjar said .

A1: could feel like summers in Georgia
RelatedSentence: If the state does nothing to curb greenhouse emissions , summers in Pennsylvania could feel like summers in Georgia , with hotter and more humid conditions , Najjar said .
Even if the state cuts emissions , Pennsylvania 's summers are still on track to feel like those in Virginia .
In winter , snow could be rare , Najjar said .

Ninety - seven percent of climate scientists agree climate - warming trends in the past century are likely the result of human activities , according to the National Academy of Sciences , NASA and other scientific associations .
Some , however , including the state 's top environmental protection officials , have questioned whether climate change would have a major impact on the planet 's inhabitants .

Dustin Brisson , an associate professor of biology at the University of Pennsylvania , will present research showing the spread of Lyme disease in the Hudson River Valley .
In 2000 , Albany County in New York had no reported cases , Brisson said .

In Allegheny County , reports of Lyme disease , caused by a bacteria transmitted to humans by ticks that can infect joints , the heart and the brain , increased last year , said Guillermo Cole , a health department spokesman .

In Allegheny County , reports of Lyme disease , caused by a bacteria transmitted to humans by ticks that can infect joints , the heart and the brain , increased last year , said Guillermo Cole , a health department spokesman .
The department received 603 reported cases in 2013 .
In 2007 , there were 32 , Cole said , noting that numbers from past years were spotty , and there are now more stringent reporting requirements .
A warming climate could be bad news for allergy sufferers , said Dr. Leonard Bielory , an allergist with a practice in New Jersey and researcher at Rutgers University .

Bielory , who will speak on Monday , said preliminary results from his research show the presence of pollen will increase 10 to 20 percent in the next 10 to 20 years , and ragweed will release pollen earlier and longer .
